text: Frances McDormand won her Oscar playing
Margie a Minnesota cop with a lot of
confidence and a thick regional accent
in the 1996 movie Fargo now on Broadway
and David lindsay-abaire very fine new
play good people MS McDormand is playing
a middle-aged South Boston gal with very
little confidence but another thick
regional accent the similarities between
those two roles end there except that
they both demonstrate MS McDormand
ability to create a complete character
from her accent to her posture to her
very metabolism that's always
surprisingly more than the sum of its
parts in good people ms McDorman plays a
woman whose very identity is tied up and
being part of Southie which is what they
call the working-class neighborhood
where she's lived all her life like many
Americans these days
mark needs a job and she hears an old
boyfriend played by Tate Donovan has
become a successful doctor so she seeks
him out what happens in the course of
the two meetings she has with him
becomes a finely detailed study in
social class and character by the end
you understand marks life from every
angle it's past its present even its
future and why South Boston will always
be part of it in every scene ms mcdorman
traces an evolution from feisty hope and
determination to get the best of the
situation to defensive anger to a very
poignant kind of fatalism er resignation
it's the arc of a life repeated over and
over again in miniature and it makes you
wonder what similar patterns there might
be in your own life now that is
illuminating acting
